outline:
Lang Markus Viehbeck
Lang contains fragments of at least three sutra collections, all of them structured in 30 volumes. Here, I will order them in the following way: Lg1-30: First, a collection called mdo sde rgyas pa on its cover. As the cover is not always preserved, it is not always clear which volumes belong to that collection. I tried to decide mainly by style and material setup. Collection could be placed, roughly speaking in 14th century. Lg31-60: Secondly, a somewhat younger, perhaps 15-16th century, and more heterogenous collection, produced over a larger period of time as it seems. Individual folios may also be much older. The order in this collection seems to be identical with that of the previous collection and I assume it was actually copied from the earlier collection. The parallels in order also confirm the principle order of the earlier collection, also with regard to the volumes that lack a cover and hence it is not entirely sure whether they belong to the collection. Several volumes of this younger collection contain prefaces, which should allow for a more precise dating of individual volumes. L61-90: Fragments of another sutra collection that appears to be slightly earlier than the first collection, perhaps early 14th century. Often these volumes are hard to distinguish from the volumes of the first collection, but there is a clear difference in the sense that all of these volumes have a significantly smaller size than those of the other collection. This earlier collection seems to differ somewhat from the setup of the other collections. At the end of the catalogue, I will add all other canonical volumes, not sure yet in which order.
Mdo 1: mdo sde rgyas pa on cover, where a cover is preserved; ca. 14th/15th c.
vol 1: there are 3 volumes of mdo skal bzang in the Lang collection, among them L3 is clearly the oldest. As the first folio is missing it contains no mention of mdo sde rgyas pa; also it differs a bit in style from the other volumes of mdo sde, as sting holes are decorated in double circles and in color, also it contains color decorations on the first few folios. The reason for this could be that it was considered special as it is the first volume, or it simply was a slightly later replacment of the original volume. Note also that this volume contains 9 lines of text, while the other volumes of mdo sde contain mostly only 8 text lines. The shape of the letters point to 14th or 15th century. Note that there is a name on folio 2, which we still have to identify: bsod nams shugs can dpon po dpal ldan.
94 Lg1.1 mdo, Ka-L312KG211174mdo sde
1b1-336a8 'phags pa bskal pa bzang po pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen po'i mdo' a r+ya bAd tra kal bi ka na na ma mA hA ya na su tra 'phags pa skal pa bzang po zhes bya ba / theg pa chen po' mdo // rdzogs s+ho // //rgya gar gyi mkhan po b+h+yid dya ka ra sing ha dang / lo tsa ba ban de dpal gyi dbyangs kyis bsgyur / zhu chen gyi lo tsha ba ban de dpal gyi brtsegs kyis / zhus te gtan la phab pa'o // End of volume contains ye dharmƒÅ hetu formula: na mo rad na kra ya ya // OM ye ...
vol 2: there are no other mdo kha volumes in the Lang collection, but one brgyud kha, which we still have to check if it is really brgyud. No mdo sde mentioned on first folio. The first 2 folios are also slightly colored, a bit similar to L3, but less elaborate. Shape of letters points to 14th or 15th century.

add later F169 contains double circle decoration, just like L3. Note that there is quite a bit of variation in the marginal title: rgya/rgya che/rol pa.

vol 5: there are 2 vols mdo ca in the Lang collection. The other one, L49, is clearly much younger. This one, L32, looks very much similar in style like to other vols of the mdo sde collection.

vol 21: mdo zha is found altogether three times in the Lang collection; of these, L61 is clearly younger. L9 and L12 are rather similar, with L9 appearing a bit older in terms of orthography and paleography. As this is a bit smaller in size, 66x20, I would opt for L12 for being rather close to the mdo sde collection.

vol 28: there are two volumes of mdo sa in the Lang collection; L8 looks very much similar in style to the other volumes of the mdo collection; it is however much smaller in size, 66x20, and also, the texts found in this volume are already contained in volume ra of the mdo sde collection. L35 on the other hand is problematic as it contains many replaced folios and appears as a mix from different periods. However, we can assume that later replacements reproduce the order of the original volume.

vol 30: there are 3 candidates in the Lang collection; L7 is definitely younger, but could be copy of older version. L21 is labelled rgyud outside, but could be mdo A as well; however the format is a bit different as every new text starts on a new page, it also does not use marginal titles; L62 is a bit different in style than the other volumes of mdo sde, with more ornamentations, just like L3, it could be part of mdo sde. I probed into the content of L7 and L62: at least the first 4 texts and the last one are identical in both volumes. It seems therefore likely that L62 is part of the collection and L7 is a younger copy.

Mdo 2: ca. 15th/16th c.? The following lists the 25 volumes, with 1 duplicate for the first volume, of what appears to be a definitively younger sutra set, perhaps produced over a larger period of time. Many of the volumes contain colophons which should allow for a more precise dating. In terms of style, the volumes are somewhat heterogenous, also this needs to be established by closer investigation. Single or no string hole as consistent feature? Volumes of this set are labelled: Lg31-60.
There are two younger volumes mdo ka, of these, L2 appears older than L1, hence the listing as Lg31a and Lg31b. Both are listed here as none of these can be ascribed to another set.

add later This is curious: it seems that at f. 318, text from the ending of the previous work and the beginning of this work has slipped into the text. This concerns f. 318a1, all text after zhi ba la gnas pa until f. 318b1, all text before gnyis su med par. The text in between is to be deleted, and it is difficult to explain how it ended up here. However, this mistake is already found in the earlier sutra collection, Lg15.12, but not in the oldest collection, Lg75.12.

####
Mdo 3: ca. early 14th c.? The following lists the 6 volumes of what seems to be an older, or at least different sutra collection. That it is indeed older than mde sde rgyas pa is seen in style, paleography and orthography, even though this will need a much more detailed investigation. The most obvious different and also coherent characteristic that applies to all these 6 volumes is the smaller format, of ca. 60 x 20 cm. This collection is labelleed: Lg61-90.
